Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Human-Inspired Safety-Preserved Agile Vehicle Maneuvers

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) project is to fundamentally understand human expert driving skills and the human-machine-environment (HME) interaction, and to design new human-inspired control of agile maneuvers for enabling the next-generation active vehicle safety technology. The proposed research is inspired by extremely agile human driving skills (e.g., professional racing car drivers and motorcycle riders) for handling and recovering unstable vehicle motion in emergencies, such as high-speed obstacle avoidance and skidding on icy roads. This CAREER project will develop new modeling and control strategies for agile-maneuvering systems, including (1) a human-driving skill-capturing framework through modeling HME dynamic interactions; (2) a new control system design for handling transient unstable vehicle motion with guaranteed-safety; (3) a new sensor-enabled tire/road interaction modeling framework for real-time predicting vehicle safety limits; and (4) experimentally testing and validation of the proposed modeling and control framework.

The proposed research will result in significant contributions, both theoretical as well as practical, in bio-inspired control of dynamic systems. The success of this CAREER project will provide new HME formulations and models, novel control strategies for tracking unstable target HME dynamics with guaranteed transient motion performance, new sensor-enabled adaptation techniques and new sensing mechanisms and models for dynamic interactions between deformable and rigid components in mechanical systems (e.g., tire/road interaction). One of the direct project outcomes is to advance active safety technology for the next-generation of ?accident-free? vehicles. The project will use online virtual driving environment development and the project website to disseminate the research outcomes, designs, models, source codes, experimental data, and documentation to the general public. In addition, the educational objectives of the project include developing a number of integrated research and education programs to attract students from underrepresented groups into engineering fields, such as active participation in the Rutgers TARGET and SUPER programs, involve undergraduate students into the research activities, and participate in international collaborations for global graduate education.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Vehicle safety is a critical global issue. The economic and societal costs of vehicular crashes are enormous and affect everyone. Although state-of-the-art active safety control systems such as anti-lock braking systems (ABS) and electronic stability control (ESC) seek to prevent vehicles from unstable motion, numerous fatal crashes still happen every day when vehicles inadvertently enter unstable motion, particularly in emergency situations such as high-speed obstacle avoidance and skidding on icy roads. Extremely skilled human drivers, such as professional racing car drivers and motorcycle riders, demonstrate superior capability to conduct seemingly unstable yet safe maneuvers. These extremely agile human driving skills motivate the proposed work on handling unstable vehicle motion in emergencies. The goal of this CAREER plan is to understand these human expert driving skills and the human-vehicle interactions, and to design new human-inspired control of agile maneuvers for enabling the next-generation ABS- or ESC-like active safety technology.

Over the past five years, working with the researchers at Ford Motor Company, the PI has accomplished a various research tasks to develop new modeling and control strategies for agile-maneuvering systems in an integrated research-education plan. The main outcomes of the project lie in several aspects: (1) a flexible pressure sensor system was developed to be embedded inside the tire rubber layer to extract the tire-road interactions force information for active safety vehicle control; (2) human expert driving skills were described and captured in systems dynamics and can be used for vehicle control systems design; (3) a new control system was developed for handling transient, unstable, agile vehicle maneuvers with guaranteed-safety; and (4) a scaled autonomous vehicle test bed was built and used to validate and demonstrate the above-mentioned theoretical findings and design. More than 27 journal and conference publications have been produced and supported by the project. Several papers have been awarded best papers or finalist at the leading international conferences in the field of mechatronics, dynamic systems and control and robotics areas. A number of research activities were integrated into the education programs to attract students from underrepresented groups into engineering fields, such as participating the Rutgers TARGET and SUPER programs and hosting more than 20 high-school and freshmen female students, supporting more than 8 senior design projects, and attracting more than 20 undergraduate students to conduct research assistance.
